info.headline: Extreme Fire Danger issued April 11 at 3:37PM CDT by NWS Sioux Falls
info.description: ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT THROUGH 9 PM FOR STRONG WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR MUCH OF SOUTH CENTRAL AND SOUTHEAST SOUTH DAKOTA, NORTHWEST IOWA AND FAR NORTHEAST NEBRASKA. ...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING FOR BREEZY WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR PORTIONS OF SOUTHEASTERN SOUTH DAKOTA, SOUTHWESTERN MN, AND NORTHWESTERN IA... ...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH WEDNESDAY EVENING FOR STRONG WINDS AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FAR NORTHEASTERN NEBRASKA, FAR SOUTHEASTERN SOUTH DAKOTA, AND MOST OF NORTHWESTERN IOWA... .DISCUSSION... Issued at 321 PM CDT Tue Apr 11 2023 Mixing continues to over perform today with favorable southerly to southwesterly winds continuing to allow for significantly warmer and drier air to pool down to the surface. As a result, temperatures have warmed into the upper 70s and low 80s this afternoon. Winds have also over performed with sustained southwesterly winds in the 20-25 mph range and gusts between 30-40 mph being reported. Relative humidity values have fallen to the 15 to 25 percent range, resulting in a large part of the area seeing near critical to critical fire weather conditions. Expect these conditions to continue through sunset tonight as the Red Flag Warning expires. Similar conditions are expected Wednesday and Thursday with a slight southeasterly shift in the main ingredients. As a result, a Red Flag Warning and Fire Weather Watch have been issued for parts of the area on Wednesday. The Red Flag Warning includes most of northwestern IA, far southeast SD, and far northeast NE. The Fire Weather Watch includes portions of southeastern SD, northwestern IA, and southwestern MN. Both the watch and warning go into effect starting at 1 pm and continue through 7 pm. People are urged to exercise extreme care with respect to outdoor activities that could cause grass fires. Avoid equipment that can cause sparks near dry grass or brush. Do not toss cigarettes on the ground. Report new fires quickly to the nearest fire department or law enforcement office. ...EXTREME FIRE DANGER... The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category this afternoon. Extreme weather conditions and very low moisture content of grasses, and other dry organic material on the ground, indicate that critical burning conditions exist. All fires have the potential to become large and spread quickly, becoming erratic with extreme behavioral characteristics. No outdoor burning should take place. OUTLOOK FOR WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON...The Grassland Fire Danger Index will reach the extreme category. The grassland fire danger product reflects fire danger for native grasses. It is not intended for cured agricultural crops, nor will it reflect conditions in road ditches which have been mowed.
